body.title: The effects of selective laser trabeculoplasty and travoprost on circadian intraocular pressure fluctuations: A randomized clinical trial.

abstract.abstracttext:
To compare the effect of selective laser
trabeculoplasty
and
travoprost
on 24-hour Intraocular Pressure fluctuations in primary open-angle glaucoma and normal-tension glaucoma .

Sixty
eyes
were included. Sixteen and 14 eyes of Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma patients were randomized to receive 360Â° Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty or 0.004% travoprost, respectively. Fourteen and 16 eyes of Normal-Tension Glaucoma patients were randomized to receive either Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty or travoprost, respectively. The 24-hour Intraocular Pressure data were collected before treatment and 6 to 8 weeks after treatment. Intraocular Pressure was measured at 2 hours intervals in the sitting position during daytime (9 Alginate Once Daily to 7 PM) and in the supine position during nighttime (9 PM to 7 Alginate Once Daily). Main outcome measure was the
percentage
of eyes that achieved posttreatment 24-hour Intraocular Pressure fluctuations <3 mmHg. Success in fluctuation reduction was defined as at least a 50% reduction in these fluctuations.

Fifty-eight eyes were analyzed. Overall, eyes in the Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty and the travoprost groups achieved a significant reduction in Intraocular Pressure compared with the baseline Intraocular Pressure values (-3.7 mmHg [P = 0.002] versus -4.1 mmHg [P < 0.001], respectively). There was no significant difference in Intraocular Pressure reduction in both groups according to type of glaucoma. During the diurnal period, 100% of Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma eyes in the travoprost group achieved posttreatment Intraocular Pressure fluctuations <3 mmHg, and 87% of eyes in the Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty group achieved the same level of fluctuations (P < 0.001). Ninety-six percent of Normal-Tension Glaucoma eyes in the travoprost group, and 82% of eyes in the Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty group had Intraocular Pressure fluctuations <3 mmHg (P = 0.01). Success in fluctuation reduction was
75%
and
92%
for the Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty and travoprost groups, respectively (P = 0.005). The effect of travoprost on Intraocular Pressure reduction in Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma and Normal-Tension Glaucoma patients was significant both during the daytime and the nighttime, while the Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty's effect was significant only during the nighttime.

Both travoprost and Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty can significantly reduce the Intraocular Pressure in patients with Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma and Normal-Tension Glaucoma. Based on habitual positions, travoprost better controls Intraocular Pressure fluctuations than Selective Laser Trabeculoplasty, especially during the daytime.
